subject:
Re: [Ip-health] oh, please: Fwd: Stop the Outsourcing of US Jobs
 to Thailand
body:
In the past, USA for Innovation has been one of the louder voices
attacking Brazil.

Also, Ken Adelman's wife, Carol works at the Hudson Institute, where she
has authored a number of industry-friendly pieces.  She is perhaps best
known for her paper which concluded generics ARVs cost more than brand
name ARVs.
(http://spp.hudson.org/files/publications/AdelmanARVWhitePaper.pdf)  She
has also attacked generic ARVs as being unsafe.


Ellen Shaffer wrote:
> --
> [ Picked text/plain from multipart/alternative ]
> Fyi: It seems that Ken Adelman, Donald Rumsfeld's former right-hand
> man, is now keeping the wolf from the door by lending his name to
> usaforinnovation.org.  The note distributed below to a Democratic
> listserv aims to undermine support for Thailand's historic compulsory
> licences by wrapping pharma's monopolistic practices in the call to
> save "American" jobs! As this list knows, drug companies are
> transnational, many not even headquartered in the US; and outsourcing
> is already their middle name. - Ellen Shaffer
>
>
>
>> []
>>
>>
>> Thailand has been taken over by a military regime hostile to good
>> American jobs in our science industries. The government is now
>> stealing the inventions of American workers to pay for inflated
>> salaries and new toys for the military.
>>
>> Worse, the Thai military is now trying to convince other nations to
>> follow its lead. The Minister of Health will be in the U.S. this
>> week to convince policymakers, academics and the press that these
>> new spending priorities are more important than the jobs of the
>> American innovators who are working to save lives.
>>
>> Take action today to let your
>> representative officials know that theft of American property by the
>> Thai government and threats to American jobs must be stopped!
>>
>> Bob Fertik
>>
>> []
>>
>>
>>
>> The Outsourcing of American Jobs to Thailand
>>
>> A military dictatorship took control of Thailand by coup last
>> September and has since been leading the latest attack on American jobs.
>>
>> The military has stolen money from Americans through the imposition
>> of capital controls, has passed new discriminatory business laws
>> against Americans working in Thailand, and is now stealing American
>> medical innovations - a direct attack on hundreds of thousands of
>> American scientists, doctors, teachers and researchers.
>>
>> The new Ministry of Health has been particularly fixated on harming
>> Americans. The military-appointed representative at the World Health
>> Organization, Dr. Suwit Wibulpolprasert, proposed in January holding
>> Western tourists hostage to bargain for flu vaccines.
>>
>> But the junta's ire is not solely directed at America - they are
>> proving themselves to be dangerous to Thailand as well.
>>
>> The new military regime overtly displayed its corruption by awarding
>> themselves pay increases of nearly $10 million and going on a
>> military spending spree surpassing the $1 billion mark.
>>
>> And just last month, Human Rights Watch issued a report critical of
>> the Thai government, accusing them in the mass "disappearances" of
>> Malay Muslims including the use of "paramilitary Army rangers and
>> village defense volunteers", putting innocent civilians at risk.
>>
>> CLICK HERE TO TAKE ACTION
>>
>> Unfortunately, President Bush and his incompetent Administration
>> have done nothing to respond.
>>
>> The Democrats must take the lead on fighting corrupt and hostile
>> trading partners. Since when did not protecting Americans become our
>> trade policy?
>>
>> Our new Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee Charles
>> Rangel (D-NY) said it best when he said that American innovators are
>> "paying for the research and development that we have in
>> intellectual property. And [if] you steal from them, you are
>> stealing from Americans."
>>
>> CLICK HERE TO TAKE ACTION
>>
>> This week, the Thai Minister of Health is holding court with
>> Administration officials, Members of Congress, academics and the
>> media in an attempt to convince these Americans that theft of
>> American products is justified in poor countries.
>>
>> While there are many issues around the world surrounding delivery of
>> medications to impoverished peoples who can't afford them, the
>> recent actions by Thailand cannot be tolerated as a viable solution.
>> Since coming to power the military has lined its pockets, kicked out
>> foreign investors, and is now stealing from American workers. Hardly
>> a poster child for the HIV/AIDS movement.
>>
>> CLICK HERE TO TAKE ACTION
>>
>> For more information about other ways you can take action, please
>> visit www.usaforinnovation.org
>>
